required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Acetated Ringer's Solution Versus Saline in Patients With Septic Shock
clinical_study.official_title: Acetated Ringer's Solution Versus Saline in Patients With Septic Shock

brief_summary.textblock: The primary aim of this trial is to compare the effect of acetated ringer's solution with that of saline for therapy on the incidence and development of major adverse renal events among septic shock patients. The investigators hypothesize that use of acetated ringer's solution for resuscitation among septic shock patients will reduce the incidence of major adverse kidney events.

detailed_description.textblock: Normal saline and Ringer's solutions are the preferred crystalloid fluids administered in early septic shock. However, evidence have associated saline with hyperchloremia and secondary metabolic acidosis, and renal vasoconstriction, increased incidence of acute kidney injury (AKI) and mortality. The primary aim of this trial is to compare the effect of acetated ringer's solution with that of saline for therapy on the incidence and development of major adverse renal events among septic shock patients. The investigators hypothesize that use of acetated ringer's solution for resuscitation among septic shock patients will reduce the incidence of major adverse kidney events.

primary_outcome.measure: Incidence of major adverse renal events in 28 days
primary_outcome.description: Incidence of major adverse renal events

arm_group.description: Use saline for fluid resuscitation during the first 72 hours after enrollment
Use acetated Ringer's solution for fluid resuscitation during the first 72 hours after enrollment

intervention.description: Use the choice of crystalloid for resuscitation during the first 72 hours after enrollment
